title: What's News: World-Wide — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 27, 2019).

Trump sought to use the powers of his office to push Ukraine to investigate Democratic rival Biden, and White House officials acted to conceal evidence of the president's actions, a whistleblower complaint alleges.

Giuliani has emerged as a key figure at the heart of the burgeoning impeachment inquiry.

The administration will cap the number of refugees allowed into the U.S. at 18,000 for the fiscal year beginning in October, a record low.

Syrian regime forces carried out a chlorine attack in May, a U.S. intelligence assessment says. Pompeo condemned such assaults.

The Senate passed a short-term funding measure to stave off a possible government shutdown after the end of the month.

France said it would cut taxes on individuals and businesses by EUR10.2 billion, as Macron seeks to revive his economic overhaul.

Afghanistan's Ghani is seeking another term as president in a Saturday vote shadowed by fears of violence and electoral fraud.

The EPA accused California of failing to comply with federal water-pollution laws, escalating the administration's feud with the state.

The Senate confirmed Eugene Scalia to be the next secretary of labor.

Died: Jacques Chirac, 86, former French president.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 27, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
